sn56.53:1.1.pli: “Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, yatthimā mahānadiyo saṃsandanti samenti, seyyathidaṃ—
sn56.53:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, there are places where the great rivers—the Ganges, Yamuna, Aciravatī, Sarabhū, and Mahī—join together and converge.

sn56.53:1.2.pli: gaṅgā, yamunā, aciravatī, sarabhū, mahī, tato puriso dve vā tīṇi vā udakaphusitāni uddhareyya.
sn56.53:1.2.eng: Suppose a person was to draw two or three drops of water from such a place.

sn56.53:1.4.pli: katamaṃ nu kho bahutaraṃ—yāni dve vā tīṇi vā udakaphusitāni ubbhatāni, yaṃ vā sambhejjaudakan”ti?
sn56.53:1.4.eng: Which is more: the two or three drops drawn out or the water in the confluence?”

sn56.53:1.5.pli: “Etadeva, bhante, bahutaraṃ, yadidaṃ—saṃbhejjaudakaṃ; appamattakāni dve vā tīṇi vā udakaphusitāni ubbhatāni.
sn56.53:1.5.eng: “Sir, the water in the confluence is certainly more. The two or three drops drawn out are tiny.

sn56.53:1.6.pli: Saṅkhampi na upenti, upanidhampi na upenti, kalabhāgampi na upenti saṃbhejjaudakaṃ upanidhāya dve vā tīṇi vā udakaphusitāni ubbhatānī”ti.
sn56.53:1.6.eng: Compared to the water in the confluence, it doesn’t count, there’s no comparison, it’s not worth a fraction.”

sn56.53:1.7.eng: “In the same way, for a noble disciple …

sn56.53:1.8.eng: That’s why you should practice meditation …”

sn56.54:1.1.pli: “Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, yatthimā mahānadiyo saṃsandanti samenti, seyyathidaṃ—
sn56.54:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, there are places where the great rivers—the Ganges, Yamuna, Aciravatī, Sarabhū, and Mahī—join together and converge.

sn56.54:1.2.pli: gaṅgā, yamunā, aciravatī, sarabhū, mahī, taṃ udakaṃ parikkhayaṃ pariyādānaṃ gaccheyya, ṭhapetvā dve vā tīṇi vā udakaphusitāni.
sn56.54:1.2.eng: Suppose that water dried up and evaporated except for two or three drops.

sn56.54:1.4.pli: katamaṃ nu kho bahutaraṃ—yaṃ vā saṃbhejjaudakaṃ parikkhīṇaṃ pariyādinnaṃ, yāni dve vā tīṇi vā udakaphusitāni avasiṭṭhānī”ti?
sn56.54:1.4.eng: Which is more: the water in the confluence that has dried up and evaporated, or the two or three drops left?”

sn56.54:1.5.pli: “Etadeva, bhante, bahutaraṃ saṃbhejjaudakaṃ yadidaṃ parikkhīṇaṃ pariyādinnaṃ; appamattakāni dve vā tīṇi vā udakaphusitāni avasiṭṭhāni.
sn56.54:1.5.eng: “Sir, the water in the confluence that has dried up and evaporated is certainly more. The two or three drops left are tiny.

sn56.54:1.6.pli: Saṅkhampi na upenti, upanidhampi na upenti, kalabhāgampi na upenti saṃbhejjaudakaṃ parikkhīṇaṃ pariyādinnaṃ upanidhāya dve vā tīṇi vā udakaphusitāni avasiṭṭhānī”ti.
sn56.54:1.6.eng: Compared to the water in the confluence that has dried up and evaporated, it doesn’t count, there’s no comparison, it’s not worth a fraction.”

sn56.54:1.7.eng: “In the same way, for a noble disciple …

sn56.54:1.8.eng: That’s why you should practice meditation …”

sn56.55:1.1.pli: “Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, puriso mahāpathaviyā satta kolaṭṭhimattiyo guḷikā upanikkhipeyya.
sn56.55:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, suppose a person was to place seven clay balls the size of jujube seeds on the great earth.

sn56.55:1.3.pli: katamaṃ nu kho bahutaraṃ—yā vā satta kolaṭṭhimattiyo guḷikā upanikkhittā, ayaṃ vā mahāpathavī”ti?
sn56.55:1.3.eng: Which is more: the seven clay balls the size of jujube seeds, or the great earth?”

sn56.55:1.4.pli: “Etadeva, bhante, bahutaraṃ, yadidaṃ—mahāpathavī; appamattikā satta kolaṭṭhimattiyo guḷikā upanikkhittā.
sn56.55:1.4.eng: “Sir, the great earth is certainly more. The seven clay balls the size of jujube seeds are tiny.

sn56.55:1.5.pli: Saṅkhampi na upenti, upanidhampi na upenti, kalabhāgampi na upenti mahāpathaviṃ upanidhāya satta kolaṭṭhimattiyo guḷikā upanikkhittā”ti.
sn56.55:1.5.eng: Compared to the great earth, they don’t count, there’s no comparison, they’re not worth a fraction.”

sn56.55:1.6.eng: “In the same way, for a noble disciple …

sn56.55:1.7.eng: That’s why you should practice meditation …”

sn56.56:1.1.pli: “Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, mahāpathavī parikkhayaṃ pariyādānaṃ gaccheyya ṭhapetvā satta kolaṭṭhimattiyo guḷikā.
sn56.56:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, suppose the great earth was worn away and eroded except for seven clay balls the size of jujube seeds.

sn56.56:1.3.pli: katamaṃ nu kho bahutaraṃ—yaṃ vā mahāpathaviyā parikkhīṇaṃ pariyādinnaṃ, yā vā satta kolaṭṭhimattiyo guḷikā avasiṭṭhā”ti?
sn56.56:1.3.eng: Which is more: the great earth that has been worn away and eroded, or the seven clay balls the size of jujube seeds that are left?”

sn56.56:1.4.pli: “Etadeva, bhante, bahutaraṃ mahāpathaviyā yadidaṃ parikkhīṇaṃ pariyādinnaṃ; appamattikā satta kolaṭṭhimattiyo guḷikā avasiṭṭhā.
sn56.56:1.4.eng: “Sir, the great earth that has been worn away and eroded is certainly more. The seven clay balls the size of jujube seeds are tiny.

sn56.56:1.5.pli: Saṅkhampi na upenti, upanidhampi na upenti, kalabhāgampi na upenti mahāpathaviyā parikkhīṇaṃ pariyādinnaṃ upanidhāya satta kolaṭṭhimattiyo guḷikā avasiṭṭhā”ti.
sn56.56:1.5.eng: Compared to the great earth that has been worn away and eroded, they don’t count, there’s no comparison, they’re not worth a fraction.”

sn56.56:1.6.eng: “In the same way, for a noble disciple …

sn56.56:1.7.eng: That’s why you should practice meditation …”

sn56.57:1.1.pli: “Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, puriso mahāsamuddato dve vā tīṇi vā udakaphusitāni uddharitāni.
sn56.57:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, suppose a man was to draw up two or three drops of water from the ocean.

sn56.57:1.3.pli: katamaṃ nu kho bahutaraṃ—yāni dve vā tīṇi vā udakaphusitāni ubbhatāni, yaṃ vā mahāsamudde udakan”ti?
sn56.57:1.3.eng: Which is more: the two or three drops drawn out or the water in the ocean?”

sn56.57:1.4.pli: “Etadeva, bhante, bahutaraṃ, yadidaṃ—mahāsamudde udakaṃ; appamattakāni dve vā tīṇi vā udakaphusitāni ubbhatāni.
sn56.57:1.4.eng: “Sir, the water in the ocean is certainly more. The two or three drops drawn out are tiny.

sn56.57:1.5.pli: Saṅkhampi na upenti, upanidhampi na upenti, kalabhāgampi na upenti mahāsamudde udakaṃ upanidhāya dve vā tīṇi vā udakaphusitāni ubbhatānī”ti.
sn56.57:1.5.eng: Compared to the water in the ocean, it doesn’t count, there’s no comparison, it’s not worth a fraction.”

sn56.57:1.6.eng: “In the same way, for a noble disciple …

sn56.57:1.7.eng: That’s why you should practice meditation …”

sn56.58:1.1.pli: “Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, mahāsamudde udakaṃ parikkhayaṃ pariyādānaṃ gaccheyya ṭhapetvā dve vā tīṇi vā udakaphusitāni.
sn56.58:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, suppose the water in the ocean dried up and evaporated except for two or three drops.

sn56.58:1.3.pli: katamaṃ nu kho bahutaraṃ—yaṃ vā mahāsamudde udakaṃ parikkhīṇaṃ pariyādinnaṃ, yāni dve vā tīṇi vā udakaphusitāni avasiṭṭhānī”ti?
sn56.58:1.3.eng: Which is more: the water in the ocean that has dried up and evaporated, or the two or three drops left?”

sn56.58:1.4.pli: “Etadeva, bhante, bahutaraṃ mahāsamudde udakaṃ yadidaṃ parikkhīṇaṃ pariyādinnaṃ; appamattakāni dve vā tīṇi vā udakaphusitāni avasiṭṭhāni.
sn56.58:1.4.eng: “Sir, the water in the ocean that has dried up and evaporated is certainly more. The two or three drops left are tiny.

sn56.58:1.5.pli: Saṅkhampi na upenti, upanidhampi na upenti, kalabhāgampi na upenti mahāsamudde udakaṃ parikkhīṇaṃ pariyādinnaṃ upanidhāya dve vā tīṇi vā udakaphusitāni avasiṭṭhānī”ti.
sn56.58:1.5.eng: Compared to the water in the ocean that has dried up and evaporated, it doesn’t count, there’s no comparison, it’s not worth a fraction.”

sn56.58:1.6.eng: “In the same way, for a noble disciple …

sn56.58:1.7.eng: That’s why you should practice meditation …”

sn56.59:1.1.pli: “Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, puriso himavato pabbatarājassa satta sāsapamattiyo pāsāṇasakkharā upanikkhipeyya.
sn56.59:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, suppose a person was to place seven pebbles the size of mustard seeds on the Himalayas, the king of mountains.

sn56.59:1.3.pli: katamaṃ nu kho bahutaraṃ—yā vā satta sāsapamattiyo pāsāṇasakkharā upanikkhittā, ayaṃ vā himavā pabbatarājā”ti?
sn56.59:1.3.eng: Which is more: the seven pebbles the size of mustard seeds, or the Himalayas, the king of mountains?”

sn56.59:1.4.pli: “Etadeva, bhante, bahutaraṃ, yadidaṃ—himavā pabbatarājā; appamattikā satta sāsapamattiyo pāsāṇasakkharā upanikkhittā.
sn56.59:1.4.eng: “Sir, the Himalayas, the king of mountains, is certainly more. The seven pebbles the size of mustard seeds are tiny.

sn56.59:1.5.pli: Saṅkhampi na upenti, upanidhampi na upenti, kalabhāgampi na upenti himavantaṃ pabbatarājānaṃ upanidhāya satta sāsapamattiyo pāsāṇasakkharā upanikkhittā”ti.
sn56.59:1.5.eng: Compared to the Himalayas, they don’t count, there’s no comparison, they’re not worth a fraction.”

sn56.59:1.6.eng: “In the same way, for a noble disciple …

sn56.59:1.7.eng: That’s why you should practice meditation …”

sn56.6:1.1.pli: “Ye hi keci, bhikkhave, atītamaddhānaṃ samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā yathābhūtaṃ abhisambuddhaṃ pakāsesuṃ, sabbe te cattāri ariyasaccāni yathābhūtaṃ abhisambuddhaṃ pakāsesuṃ.

sn56.6:1.2.pli: Ye hi keci, bhikkhave, anāgatamaddhānaṃ samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā yathābhūtaṃ abhisambuddhaṃ pakāsessanti, sabbe te cattāri ariyasaccāni yathābhūtaṃ abhisambuddhaṃ pakāsessanti.

sn56.6:1.3.pli: Ye hi keci, bhikkhave, etarahi samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā yathābhūtaṃ abhisambuddhaṃ pakāsenti, sabbe te cattāri ariyasaccāni yathābhūtaṃ abhisambuddhaṃ pakāsenti.
sn56.6:1.3.eng: or present—reveal that they are awakened, all of them reveal that they truly awakened to the four noble truths.

sn56.6:2.2.eng: The noble truths of suffering, the origin of suffering, the cessation of suffering, and the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering. …

sn56.6:2.3.pli: Ye hi keci, bhikkhave, atītamaddhānaṃ samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā yathābhūtaṃ abhisambuddhaṃ pakāsesuṃ …pe…

sn56.6:2.5.pli: pakāsenti, sabbe te imāni cattāri ariyasaccāni yathābhūtaṃ abhisambuddhaṃ pakāsenti.

sn56.6:3.1.pli: Tasmātiha, bhikkhave, ‘idaṃ dukkhan’ti yogo karaṇīyo …pe… ‘ayaṃ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti yogo karaṇīyo”ti.
sn56.6:3.1.eng: That’s why you should practice meditation …”

sn56.60:1.1.pli: “Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, himavā pabbatarājā parikkhayaṃ pariyādānaṃ gaccheyya, ṭhapetvā satta sāsapamattiyo pāsāṇasakkharā.
sn56.60:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, suppose the Himalayas, the king of mountains, was worn away and eroded except for seven pebbles the size of mustard seeds.

sn56.60:1.3.pli: katamaṃ nu kho bahutaraṃ—yaṃ vā himavato pabbatarājassa parikkhīṇaṃ pariyādinnaṃ, yā vā satta sāsapamattiyo pāsāṇasakkharā avasiṭṭhā”ti?
sn56.60:1.3.eng: Which is more: the portion of the Himalayas, the king of mountains, that has been worn away and eroded, or the seven pebbles the size of mustard seeds that are left?”

sn56.60:1.4.pli: “Etadeva, bhante, bahutaraṃ himavato pabbatarājassa yadidaṃ parikkhīṇaṃ pariyādinnaṃ; appamattikā satta sāsapamattiyo pāsāṇasakkharā avasiṭṭhā.
sn56.60:1.4.eng: “Sir, the portion of the Himalayas, the king of mountains, that has been worn away and eroded is certainly more. The seven pebbles the size of mustard seeds are tiny.

sn56.60:1.5.pli: Saṅkhampi na upenti, upanidhampi na upenti, kalabhāgampi na upenti himavato pabbatarājassa parikkhīṇaṃ pariyādinnaṃ upanidhāya satta sāsapamattiyo pāsāṇasakkharā avasiṭṭhā”ti.
sn56.60:1.5.eng: Compared to the Himalayas, they don’t count, there’s no comparison, they’re not worth a fraction.”

sn56.60:1.6.pli: “Evameva kho, bhikkhave, ariyasāvakassa diṭṭhisampannassa puggalassa abhisametāvino etadeva bahutaraṃ dukkhaṃ yadidaṃ parikkhīṇaṃ pariyādinnaṃ; appamattakaṃ avasiṭṭhaṃ.
sn56.60:1.6.eng: “In the same way, for an individual with comprehension, a noble disciple accomplished in view, the suffering that’s over and done with is more, what’s left is tiny.

sn56.60:1.7.pli: Saṅkhampi na upeti, upanidhampi na upeti, kalabhāgampi na upeti, purimaṃ dukkhakkhandhaṃ parikkhīṇaṃ pariyādinnaṃ upanidhāya yadidaṃ sattakkhattuparamatā;
sn56.60:1.7.eng: Compared to the mass of suffering in the past that’s over and done with, it doesn’t count, there’s no comparison, it’s not worth a fraction, since there are at most seven more lives.

sn56.60:1.8.pli: yo ‘idaṃ dukkhan’ti yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti …pe… ‘ayaṃ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti.
sn56.60:1.8.eng: Such an individual truly understands about suffering, its origin, its cessation, and the path.

sn56.60:2.1.pli: Tasmātiha, bhikkhave, ‘idaṃ dukkhan’ti yogo karaṇīyo …pe… ‘ayaṃ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti yogo karaṇīyo”ti.
sn56.60:2.1.eng: That’s why you should practice meditation …”

sn56.61:1.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā parittaṃ nakhasikhāyaṃ paṃsuṃ āropetvā bhikkhū āmantesi:
sn56.61:1.1.eng: Then the Buddha, picking up a little bit of dirt on his fingernail, addressed the mendicants:

sn56.61:1.3.pli: katamaṃ nu kho bahutaraṃ—yo vāyaṃ mayā paritto nakhasikhāyaṃ paṃsu āropito, ayaṃ vā mahāpathavī”ti?
sn56.61:1.3.eng: Which is more: the little bit of dirt on my fingernail, or this great earth?”

sn56.61:1.4.pli: “Etadeva, bhante, bahutaraṃ, yadidaṃ—mahāpathavī; appamattakāyaṃ bhagavatā paritto nakhasikhāyaṃ paṃsu āropito.
sn56.61:1.4.eng: “Sir, the great earth is certainly more. The little bit of dirt on your fingernail is tiny.

sn56.61:1.5.pli: Saṅkhampi na upeti, upanidhampi na upeti, kalabhāgampi na upeti mahāpathaviṃ upanidhāya bhagavatā paritto nakhasikhāyaṃ paṃsu āropito”ti.
sn56.61:1.5.eng: Compared to the great earth, it doesn’t count, there’s no comparison, it’s not worth a fraction.”

sn56.61:2.1.pli: “Evameva kho, bhikkhave, appamattakā te sattā ye manussesu paccājāyanti; atha kho eteva bahutarā sattā ye aññatra manussehi paccājāyanti.
sn56.61:2.1.eng: “In the same way, the sentient beings reborn as humans are few, while those not reborn as humans are many.

sn56.61:2.3.eng: It’s because they haven’t seen the four noble truths.

sn56.61:2.5.eng: The noble truths of suffering, its origin, its cessation, and the path.

sn56.61:3.1.pli: Tasmātiha, bhikkhave, ‘idaṃ dukkhan’ti yogo karaṇīyo …pe… ‘ayaṃ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti yogo karaṇīyo”ti.
sn56.61:3.1.eng: That’s why you should practice meditation …”

sn56.62:1.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā parittaṃ nakhasikhāyaṃ paṃsuṃ āropetvā bhikkhū āmantesi:
sn56.62:1.1.eng: Then the Buddha, picking up a little bit of dirt on his fingernail, addressed the mendicants:

sn56.62:1.3.pli: katamaṃ nu kho bahutaraṃ—yo vāyaṃ mayā paritto nakhasikhāyaṃ paṃsu āropito, ayaṃ vā mahāpathavī”ti?
sn56.62:1.3.eng: Which is more: the little bit of dirt on my fingernail, or this great earth?”

sn56.62:1.4.pli: “Etadeva, bhante, bahutaraṃ, yadidaṃ—mahāpathavī; appamattakāyaṃ bhagavatā paritto nakhasikhāyaṃ paṃsu āropito.
sn56.62:1.4.eng: “Sir, the great earth is certainly more. The little bit of dirt on your fingernail is tiny.

sn56.62:1.5.pli: Saṅkhampi na upeti, upanidhampi na upeti, kalabhāgampi na upeti mahāpathaviṃ upanidhāya bhagavatā paritto nakhasikhāyaṃ paṃsu āropito”ti.
sn56.62:1.5.eng: Compared to the great earth, it doesn’t count, there’s no comparison, it’s not worth a fraction.”

sn56.62:2.1.pli: “Evameva kho, bhikkhave, appamattakā te sattā ye majjhimesu janapadesu paccājāyanti; atha kho eteva bahutarā sattā ye paccantimesu janapadesu paccājāyanti aviññātāresu milakkhesu …pe….
sn56.62:2.1.eng: “In the same way, the sentient beings reborn in central countries are few, while those reborn in the borderlands, among uneducated foreigners, are many. …”

sn56.63:1.1.pli: … “Evameva kho, bhikkhave, appakā te sattā ye pana ariyena paññācakkhunā samannāgatā; atha kho eteva bahutarā sattā ye avijjāgatā sammuḷhā …pe….
sn56.63:1.1.eng: “… the sentient beings who have the noble eye of wisdom are few, while those who are ignorant and confused are many. …”

sn56.64:1.1.pli: … “Evameva kho, bhikkhave, appakā te sattā ye surāmerayamajjappamādaṭṭhānā paṭiviratā; atha kho eteva bahutarā sattā ye surāmerayamajjappamādaṭṭhānā apaṭiviratā …pe….
sn56.64:1.1.eng: “… the sentient beings who refrain from beer, wine, and liquor intoxicants, are few, while those who don’t refrain are many. …”

sn56.65:1.1.pli: … “Evameva kho, bhikkhave, appakā te sattā ye thalajā; atha kho eteva bahutarā sattā ye udakajā. Taṃ kissa hetu …pe….
sn56.65:1.1.eng: “… the sentient beings born on land are few, while those born in water are many. …”

sn56.66:1.1.pli: … “Evameva kho, bhikkhave, appakā te sattā ye matteyyā; atha kho eteva bahutarā sattā ye amatteyyā …pe….
sn56.66:1.1.eng: “… the sentient beings who respect their mothers are few, while those who don’t are many. …”

sn56.67:1.1.pli: … “Evameva kho, bhikkhave, appakā te sattā ye petteyyā; atha kho eteva bahutarā sattā ye apetteyyā …pe….
sn56.67:1.1.eng: “… the sentient beings who respect their fathers are few, while those who don’t are many. …”

sn56.68:1.1.pli: … “Evameva kho, bhikkhave, appakā te sattā ye sāmaññā; atha kho eteva bahutarā sattā ye asāmaññā …pe….
sn56.68:1.1.eng: “… the sentient beings who respect ascetics are few, while those who don’t are many. …”

sn56.69:1.1.pli: … “Evameva kho, bhikkhave, appakā te sattā ye brahmaññā; atha kho eteva bahutarā sattā ye abrahmaññā …pe….
sn56.69:1.1.eng: “… the sentient beings who respect brahmins are few, while those who don’t are many. …”

sn56.7:1.1.pli: “Mā, bhikkhave, pāpake akusale vitakke vitakkeyyātha, seyyathidaṃ—
sn56.7:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, don’t think bad, unskillful thoughts, such as

sn56.7:1.4.pli: Nete, bhikkhave, vitakkā atthasaṃhitā nādibrahmacariyakā na nibbidāya na virāgāya na nirodhāya na upasamāya na abhiññāya na sambodhāya na nibbānāya saṃvattanti.
sn56.7:1.4.eng: Because those thoughts aren’t beneficial or relevant to the fundamentals of the spiritual life. They don’t lead to disillusionment, dispassion, cessation, peace, insight, awakening, and extinguishment.

sn56.7:2.1.pli: Vitakkentā ca kho tumhe, bhikkhave, ‘idaṃ dukkhan’ti vitakkeyyātha, ‘ayaṃ dukkhasamudayo’ti vitakkeyyātha, ‘ayaṃ dukkhanirodho’ti vitakkeyyātha, ‘ayaṃ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti vitakkeyyātha.
sn56.7:2.1.eng: When you think, you should think: ‘This is suffering’ … ‘This is the origin of suffering’ … ‘This is the cessation of suffering’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering’.

sn56.7:2.3.pli: Ete, bhikkhave, vitakkā atthasaṃhitā ete ādibrahmacariyakā ete nibbidāya virāgāya nirodhāya upasamāya abhiññāya sambodhāya nibbānāya saṃvattanti.
sn56.7:2.3.eng: Because those thoughts are beneficial and relevant to the fundamentals of the spiritual life. They lead to disillusionment, dispassion, cessation, peace, insight, awakening, and extinguishment.

sn56.7:3.1.pli: Tasmātiha, bhikkhave, ‘idaṃ dukkhan’ti yogo karaṇīyo …pe… ‘ayaṃ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti yogo karaṇīyo”ti.
sn56.7:3.1.eng: That’s why you should practice meditation …”

sn56.70:1.1.pli: … “Evameva kho, bhikkhave, appakā te sattā ye kule jeṭṭhāpacāyino; atha kho eteva bahutarā sattā ye kule ajeṭṭhāpacāyinoti …pe….
sn56.70:1.1.eng: “… the sentient beings who honor the elders in the family are few, while those who don’t are many. …”

sn56.71:1.1.pli: … “Evameva kho, bhikkhave, appakā te sattā ye pāṇātipātā paṭiviratā; atha kho eteva bahutarā sattā ye pāṇātipātā appaṭiviratā.
sn56.71:1.1.eng: “… the sentient beings who refrain from killing living creatures are few, while those who don’t refrain are many. …”

sn56.72:1.1.pli: … “Evameva kho, bhikkhave, appakā te sattā ye adinnādānā paṭiviratā; atha kho eteva bahutarā sattā ye adinnādānā appaṭiviratā …pe….
sn56.72:1.1.eng: “… the sentient beings who refrain from stealing are few, while those who don’t refrain are many. …”

sn56.73:1.1.pli: … “Evameva kho, bhikkhave, appakā te sattā ye kāmesumicchācārā paṭiviratā; atha kho eteva bahutarā sattā ye kāmesumicchācārā appaṭiviratā …pe….
sn56.73:1.1.eng: “… the sentient beings who refrain from sexual misconduct are few, while those who don’t refrain are many. …”

sn56.74:1.1.pli: … “Evameva kho, bhikkhave, appakā te sattā ye musāvādā paṭiviratā; atha kho eteva bahutarā sattā ye musāvādā appaṭiviratā …pe….
sn56.74:1.1.eng: “… the sentient beings who refrain from lying are few, while those who don’t refrain are many. …”

sn56.75:1.1.pli: … “Evameva kho, bhikkhave, appakā te sattā ye pisuṇāya vācāya paṭiviratā; atha kho eteva bahutarā sattā ye pisuṇāya vācāya appaṭiviratā …pe….
sn56.75:1.1.eng: “… the sentient beings who refrain from divisive speech are few, while those who don’t refrain are many. …”

sn56.76:1.1.pli: … “Evameva kho, bhikkhave, appakā te sattā ye pharusāya vācāya paṭiviratā; atha kho eteva bahutarā sattā ye pharusāya vācāya appaṭiviratā …pe….
sn56.76:1.1.eng: “… the sentient beings who refrain from harsh speech are few, while those who don’t refrain are many. …”

sn56.77:1.1.pli: … “Evameva kho, bhikkhave, appakā te sattā ye samphappalāpā paṭiviratā; atha kho eteva bahutarā sattā ye samphappalāpā appaṭiviratā …pe….
sn56.77:1.1.eng: “… the sentient beings who refrain from talking nonsense are few, while those who don’t refrain are many. …”

sn56.78:1.1.pli: … “Evameva kho, bhikkhave, appakā te sattā ye bījagāmabhūtagāmasamārambhā paṭiviratā; atha kho eteva bahutarā sattā ye bījagāmabhūtagāmasamārambhā appaṭiviratā …pe….
sn56.78:1.1.eng: “… the sentient beings who refrain from injuring plants and seeds are few, while those who don’t refrain are many. …”

sn56.79:1.1.pli: … “Evameva kho, bhikkhave, appakā te sattā ye vikālabhojanā paṭiviratā; atha kho eteva bahutarā sattā ye vikālabhojanā appaṭiviratā …pe….
sn56.79:1.1.eng: “… the sentient beings who refrain from food at the wrong time are few, while those who don’t refrain are many. …”

sn56.8:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, don’t think up a bad, unskillful idea.

sn56.8:1.2.pli: ‘sassato loko’ti vā ‘asassato loko’ti vā, ‘antavā loko’ti vā ‘anantavā loko’ti vā, ‘taṃ jīvaṃ taṃ sarīran’ti vā ‘aññaṃ jīvaṃ aññaṃ sarīran’ti vā, ‘hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā’ti vā ‘na hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā’ti vā, ‘hoti ca na ca hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā’ti vā, ‘neva hoti na na hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā’ti vā.
sn56.8:1.2.eng: For example: the cosmos is eternal, or not eternal, or finite, or infinite; the soul and the body are one and the same, or the soul is one thing, the body another; after death, a realized one still exists, or no longer exists, or both still exists and no longer exists, or neither still exists nor no longer exists.

sn56.8:1.4.pli: Nesā, bhikkhave, cintā atthasaṃhitā nādibrahmacariyakā na nibbidāya na virāgāya na nirodhāya na upasamāya na abhiññāya na sambodhāya na nibbānāya saṃvattati.
sn56.8:1.4.eng: Because those thoughts aren’t beneficial or relevant to the fundamentals of the spiritual life. They don’t lead to disillusionment, dispassion, cessation, peace, insight, awakening, and extinguishment.

sn56.8:2.1.pli: Cintentā ca kho tumhe, bhikkhave, ‘idaṃ dukkhan’ti cinteyyātha, ‘ayaṃ dukkhasamudayo’ti cinteyyātha, ‘ayaṃ dukkhanirodho’ti cinteyyātha, ‘ayaṃ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti cinteyyātha.
sn56.8:2.1.eng: When you think something up, you should think: ‘This is suffering’ … ‘This is the origin of suffering’ … ‘This is the cessation of suffering’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering’.

sn56.8:2.3.pli: Esā, bhikkhave, cintā atthasaṃhitā, esā ādibrahmacariyakā, esā nibbidāya virāgāya nirodhāya upasamāya abhiññāya sambodhāya nibbānāya saṃvattati.
sn56.8:2.3.eng: Because those thoughts are beneficial and relevant to the fundamentals of the spiritual life. They lead to disillusionment, dispassion, cessation, peace, insight, awakening, and extinguishment.

sn56.8:3.1.pli: Tasmātiha, bhikkhave, ‘idaṃ dukkhan’ti yogo karaṇīyo …pe… ‘ayaṃ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti yogo karaṇīyo”ti.
sn56.8:3.1.eng: That’s why you should practice meditation …”

sn56.80:1.1.pli: … “Evameva kho, bhikkhave, appakā te sattā ye mālāgandhavilepanadhāraṇamaṇḍanavibhūsanaṭṭhānā paṭiviratā; atha kho eteva bahutarā sattā ye mālāgandhavilepanadhāraṇamaṇḍanavibhūsanaṭṭhānā appaṭiviratā …pe….
sn56.80:1.1.eng: “… the sentient beings who refrain from attiring and adorning themselves with garlands, fragrance, and makeup are few, while those who don’t refrain are many …”

sn56.81:1.2.pli: “Evameva kho, bhikkhave, appakā te sattā ye naccagītavāditavisūkadassanā paṭiviratā; atha kho eteva bahutarā sattā ye naccagītavāditavisūkadassanā appaṭiviratā. Taṃ kissa hetu …pe….
sn56.81:1.2.eng: “… the sentient beings who refrain from seeing shows of dancing, singing, and music  are few, while those who don’t refrain are many …”
